title: Zimbabwe: Minister Mpofu in Bid to Fire Owed Workers in Line With Chidyausiku Ruling
text:
Zimbabwe: Stop Corruption, Kasukuwere Fumes 
"We write to advice that the employer has decided to exercise its right in terms of the common law and Section 12(4) of the Labour Act Chapter 28:01(Hereinafter referred in the Labour Act) and clause 1 of your contract to terminate your contract of employment on notice with immediate effect. 
"In this regard, you are hereby given three months in terms of the provisions of Section 12(4) of the Labour act," said the letter. 
"For the record, the termination had not been done in terms of any industrial code because it is not termination of misconduct but termination on notice as per the provisions of the Labour Act and Common Law". 
The more than 20 journalists and dozens of support staff have already dragged Mpofu to the Labour Court. The matter is soon to be heard before an arbitrator. 
The journalists suspect that Mpofu wants to undercut that process through his letter which they declined to accept. 
"We will not accept the letters; if Mpofu is sincere then his letters should be dated anything after the date the Supreme Court judgment was issued," said an employee on condition of anonymity. 
Mpofu's letter added: "The employer absolves you from your duty to render service for the three months with effect from 20 March 2015 and also for the remaining days of March 2015. 
"Accordingly you shall be paid your outstanding salary and the notice pay for the said three months you are at home. You shall be entitled to your terminal benefits as per the provisions of Section 13 of the Labour Act". 
The Supreme Court ruling has inspired massive job losses in Zimbabwe's already comatose economy with labour experts urging Mugabe to use his presidential powers to stop the carnage. 
According to conservative estimates more than 2000 jobs have been lost. Zimbabwe
